acute_aquatic_toxicity.hazard_name: Hazardous to the aquatic environment Acute

acute_toxicity_inhalation_dust.hazard_name: Acute toxicity Inhalation: Dusts and mists
acute_toxicity_inhalation_dust.rationale: Nitric acid did not exist as steam and gas, and it considered that all the data of LC50 was mist. Since all of five data were within the range of 0.05 - 0.5mg/L, it was set as Category 2.

acute_toxicity_oral.rationale: Although there is a lethal (IUCLID (2000)) statement of 430 mg/kg in humans, there is no other data and it cannot be classified.

aspiration_hazard.hazard_statement: May be fatal if swallowed and enters airways
aspiration_hazard.rationale: It was classified into Category 1 based on the statement that of chemical lobar pneumonia by aspiration (ACGIH (2001)).

carcinogenicity.rationale: There is a result in the inhalation exposure test report of two cases using rats that shows no carcinogenicity (DFGOTvol.3 (1991), (IUCLID (2000)). But there is no report of evaluation organizations, such as IARC, therefore it cannot be classified.

chronic_aquatic_toxicity.hazard_name: Hazardous to the aquatic environment Long-term
chronic_aquatic_toxicity.rationale: Classification not possible due to lack of data

corrosive_to_metals.rationale: There is no data and it cannot be classified. (a stainless steel, aluminum, and glass are durable as a container. Steels, Monel metal, nickels and coppers are corroded. There is a description as (Hommmel (1991)) and it is presumed as Category 1.)

explosives.rationale: Not an explosive product, though containing chemical groups associated with explosive properties present.

flammable_gases.hazard_name: Flammable gases including chemically unstable gases

germ_cell_mutagenicity.rationale: Although there is a report of negative results from the in vitro Ames test (DFGOTvol.3 (1991)), the substance cannot be classified because there are no reports about in vivo tests.

oxidizing_liquids.rationale: Category 3 because of UNRTDG Subsidiary risks Class: 5.1, PG III, though it is a strong oxidizing agent (NFPA, 13th, 2002)

reproductive_toxicity.rationale: Although there is the description that teratogenicity and ferotoxity does not occur and there is only a slight ossification inhibition of cranial bone in embryo in the drinking water administration test to pregnancy rat (IUCLID (2000)), but it is considered as insufficient data for classification, and it is considered as it cannot be classified.

self_reactive_substances.rationale: Although it excludes the grouping relevant to autoreactive in a molecule and includes atomic team which relates to explosibility, it is classified into the oxidizing liquid. So it is excepted from the definition of autoreactive from the statement of the GHS documents 2.8.1.

serious_eye_damage_irritation.rationale: There is a statement that if exposed to the human eye, severe burns will take place, and muddiness of a cornea and visual impairment result in vision loss (ACGIH (2001)). And it was set as Category 1 since skin corrosivity / irritation was categoried into Category 1A.

skin_corrosion_irritation.hazard_statement: Causes severe skin burns and eye damage
skin_corrosion_irritation.rationale: There is a description of corrosivity on humans (ICSC (1994)) and (HSDB (2005)), and its UN classification is class 8I, it was classified  as Category 1A.

substances_mixtures_emit_flammable_gas_i.hazard_name: Substances and mixtures which, in contact with water, emit flammable gases
substances_mixtures_emit_flammable_gas_i.rationale: The chemical structure of the substance does not contain metals or metaloids(B, Si, P, Ge, As, Se, Sn, Sb, Te, Bi, Po, At).

systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.hazard_name: Specific target organ toxicity - Repeated exposure
systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.hazard_statement: Cause damage to organs through prolonged or repeated exposure (tooth, respiratory system)
systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.rationale: According to the statement of the chronic bronchitis by occupation exposure of the steam generated from mist or nitric acid (ACGIH (2001)) and erosion of tooth (ACGIH (2001),  (DFGOTvol.3 (1994)), it was classified to as Category 1 (tooth, respiratory system).

systemic_toxicity_single_exposure.hazard_name: Specific target organ toxicity - Single exposure
systemic_toxicity_single_exposure.rationale: According to the statements that when humans inhale the steam generated from nitrate, irritation of the upper airway, coughing, breathing difficulty, pain of the breast or pulmonary are caused depending on the exposure concentration and exposure time (ACGIH (2001), DFGOTvol.3 (1991), ICSC(J), (1994), and HSDB (2005)). So it was classified into Category 1. (respiratory systems).
